docs.lead_paragraph: Out on the campaign trail, Gov. George W. Bush appears to be barely breaking a sweat these days. Town hall meetings where large audiences are free to ask questions vanished months ago when Senator John McCain of Arizona, a master of spontaneity, disappeared from the presidential race. Now audiences rarely get to ask Mr. Bush anything.

headline.main: BUSH TRAIL TAKES ROSE GARDEN TURN

docs.abstract: Gov George W Bush takes low-key approach to presidential campaigning, running a modified version of incumbent's Rose Garden strategy, which makes him appear to be governing rather than campaigning; his style and schedule are deliberate, reflecting campaign's confidence that he can mold his image by carefully choreographing television images in battleground states; aides say method has produced good results, putting him ahead in many crucial states and made him competitive in ones Democrats had counted on (M)
docs.snippet: Out on the campaign trail, Gov. George W. Bush appears to be barely breaking a sweat these days.     Town hall meetings where large audiences are free to ask questions vanished months ago when Senator John McCain of Arizona, a master of spontaneity,...

docs.lead_paragraph: SHE came here from Nigeria with her little daughter three years ago, hoping for a reunion and a fresh start with the man she had married in a traditional Yoruba ceremony at home. But life had plans other than happiness for Mosunmola Adamolekun. The story, Ms. Adamolekun and her Legal Aid lawyers say, began in Nigeria in 1990 when Ms. Adamolekun, now 38, was married. Her husband then left Nigeria and came to the United States and became a permanent resident. She came here expecting that she would become a citizen.

headline.main: When Happiness Is Too Much to Ask For

docs.abstract: Felicia Lee Coping column recounts plight of Mosunmola Adamolekun, woman who emigrated to New York City from Nigeria with her young daughter three years ago in hope of reuniting with her husband; reunion failed and she underwent surgery for brain cancer but is ineligible for even bare-bones welfare benefits because she is illegal immigrant; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Continuing his assault on Gov. George W. Bush's record in Texas, Vice President Al Gore presented his own economic proposals today as ''tried and true,'' while Governor Bush, he said, had made a ''mess'' in Texas. Mr. Gore was addressing his ideological soul mates here at a convention of the Democratic Leadership Council, the centrist organization that he helped found 15 years ago.

headline.main: Gore Contrasts His Policies With Bush's 'Mess' in Texas

docs.abstract: Vice Pres Al Gore, continuing his assault on Gov George W Bush's record in Texas, presents his own economic proposals as 'tried and true,' while contending that Bush had made 'a mess' in Texas (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN he was diagnosed with multiple sclerosis six years ago, Keith Fields, an avid boater and fisherman, was living with his girlfriend in Ronkonkoma and working as an alarm installation technician. Today, at age 33, he can't even move his arms. His mother, Dianne Davis, who oversees his care while working full-time as a hairdresser, said that when his symptoms worsened about three years ago, she hired home health aides through certified agencies. But when the aides repeatedly failed to show up, Mr. Fields's girlfriend persuaded him to go into a nursing home.

headline.main: Home Health Care Aides Are in Demand, but in Short Supply

docs.abstract: Article on severe shortage of home health care aides on Long Islanders, NY; many local health care aides have taken other, less demanding, jobs in food service or retail as good economy keeps jobless rate low; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: TUPPERWARE, not software. Maybe that should be my new motto as I consider joining the ranks of those who sell polyethylene fridgeware for a living. Think about it. Selling Tupperware has an awful lot in common with the new-economy jobs that young adults crave. You can work any time you want and as much as you want. The biggest rewards go to those who are the most immersed, the most passionate, the most relentless. No soul-deadening shirt-and-tie office environment here: your workplace is the friendliest, funkiest available -- your own home. No health insurance, pension plans or other young-people-don't-need-'em benefits to bite into the paycheck -- just plenty of incentive-based compensation, plus perks like free cars (a Jeep Cherokee! a Dodge Caravan!) and vacations (Myrtle Beach! Las Vegas!) for hitting goals. They could call it www.tupperware.com.
docs.abstract: Abby Ellin Preludes column draws parallels between hot new-economy jobs and selling Tupperware, following visit to www.tupperware.com Web site; notes Tupperware maintains million-strong army of consultants worldwide, with 75,000 in US; illustration (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: FOR 25 years, the Arts Council of Rockland has put together an annual exhibition of work done in a variety of media by artists at differing levels of talent. What ties the show together is that all the artists are older residents of Rockland County. Mark Judelson, the director of the Arts Council of Rockland, talked recently about the project.

headline.main: AT THE GALLERY WITH/Mark Judelson; From Older Artists, Works That Mirror Lifelong Experiences

docs.abstract: Interview with Mark Judelson, director of Arts Council of Rockland who comments on annual exhibition of work done in variety of media by artists at differing levels of talent who are all older residents of Rockland County, NY; photo (M)
docs.snippet: FOR 25 years, the Arts Council of Rockland has put together an annual exhibition of work done in a variety of media by artists at differing levels of talent. What ties the show together is that all the artists are older residents of Rockland County. ...

docs.lead_paragraph: If Jacob Goldman has it right, the next great real estate rush in Manhattan will be to Cooperative Village, a mostly Jewish neighborhood just south of the Williamsburg Bridge that gained some fame as the home of the bubbe in the movie ''Crossing Delancey.'' As if to prove it, Mr. Goldman, a lawyer who recently obtained his real estate broker's license, has hung a $975,000 price tag on one apartment there, although he has hopes the final sale price will be even higher. Last week, he showed a reporter his prized listing: a three-bedroom, two-bath apartment with plenty of closets (''Eleven!'' he says, running from room to room), ample Internet and cable connections and the largest kitchen counter the seller could find.

headline.main: Free Market Comes To Lower East Side; As Co-op Price Caps Are Lifted, Some Residents Are Wary of Change

docs.abstract: Apartment prices have soared at Cooperative Village, Manhattan co-op complex where owners recently voted to end price caps and charge market prices; shift is attracting real estate brokers seeking listings; map; diagram; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: William Roth, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, rattled his fellow Republicans this week by offering a plan to add prescription drugs to Medicare that resembles proposals by Congressional Democrats and the White House. The Roth plan repudiates the ill-conceived Republican bill that passed the House and provides a plausible platform for a bipartisan agreement -- though probably not before the elections. Under the House bill, only private insurers would offer coverage to the elderly. But even some private insurers regard the bill as unworkable. Mr. Roth concedes as much by proposing instead a plan that would have the government, as well as private plans, offer drug coverage. Mr. Roth's bill goes far beyond offering a drug benefit, however, embracing a reform for the entire Medicare program that mirrors proposals by President Clinton, a majority of the bipartisan Congressional committee on Medicare reform and a wide swath of health experts.
docs.abstract: Editorial welcomes Sen William Roth's plan to add prescription drugs to Medicare, saying it repudiates the ill-conceived bill passed by his fellow Republicans in House and provides a plausible platform for a bipartisan agreement (M)
